testimony:
Mr Chairman, the next witness will be Mr J.H. Kruger.  His evidence you 
will find at B, page 59.

Mr Kruger, you are an applicant for amnesty before 
this Committee and you have filled in the prescribed form.  Have you got your amnesty 
application in front of you?

Have you read through it and do you confirm that the information contained 
therein, is as far as you knowledge goes, true and correct?

It is true and correct, I just want to make a small amendment.  Also at 
paragraph 8(b), page 2, point number 6.
	In 1986 I became an Officer, that should be 1988.

Apart from that change, you are happy that the rest is all correct?  
	Reference was made to certain documents which you are going to ask to have 
incorporated into your application.  It is a document submitted by the Foundation for 
Equality before the Law and General Van der Merwe's submission to the Truth Commission 
and you are requesting on page 60 of B, that the application of Mr Erwee be incorporated 
into your application in respect of the facts and the incident itself?
You have listened to the evidence of the other applicants who testified here.
Yes, I listened to all the evidence.

Now, apart from Mr Sehlwana's evidence, do you differ substantially with 
their evidence in any way?
No, I don't have any differences with that.  I agree with it, yes.

Could you tell the Committee where were you placed on the day of the 10th 
of July?
On the 10th of July I was in the casper.

You've heard Mr Erwee's evidence inter alia as to how the casper moved into 
the road and what happened further.  Is there anything which you observed or heard which is 
different to what Mr Erwee testified and or the last witness Mr Swarts' evidence?
No, I agree with Mr Erwee's evidence entirely.
Did you also answer the fire which came from the combi that day?
How many rounds did you fire?

I didn't change magazines, so there are 20 bullets in a magazine, therefore I 
think I shot between 10 and 12 rounds.
Where were you aiming your gun when you shot?
Were you the first person to shoot or did somebody else shoot first?

I was definitely not the first to shoot.  To my right were people who started 
firing and after that I realised that there were problems and I also started firing.

How did you understand your instructions as to what was to happen with the 
passengers of the combi?

It was made clear to me that an arrest should be made and that the people 
who were in the combi, had to be arrested.
Were your instructions to do so at all costs?

Mr Visser, it intrigues me that you keep on asking to arrest at all cost, is 
wasn't at all costs?

It intrigues me that you keep on asking the witnesses whether they were at all 
costs to arrest, it was not at all costs?  But I understand you of course.

I don't want to ask a leading question, but if you will allow me, I will do it 
and we can save time.

Yes, you were instructed to do everything possible to arrest them, but not at 
the expense of your own lives?

Thank you Chairperson.  According to you, did you carry out your 
instructions as a policeman and your specific instructions on that day?
Do you think you did anything wrong?
No, I don't think I did anything wrong.
Why did you apply for amnesty?

Last year, November, I saw reports in the media and heard reports on the 
radio and the general import of this was that people should come forward and ask for 
amnesty.
	Our National Commissioner also appealed to the members to apply for amnesty if 
they had any doubt as to whether they should or not.  I spoke to people and they told me it 
wasn't necessary to apply for amnesty.  I was in doubt and I also spoke to Mr Erwee and it 
then became clear that there was apparently an investigation into the incident and that made 
me apply for amnesty.
Is that where your doubt arose?

Mr Swarts testified that he secured the scene there.  Did you have any role to 
play in that?

Yes.  Just to explain very briefly as an explosives expert it is policy that 
usually only one person goes forward to the scene where there could possibly be explosives 
or where explosives had to be disposed of.
	I stood close to Mr Swarts and I helped him.   For instance as he took explosives out 
of the bus, he passed it onto me and I then just took it further away and guarded it, so that 
nobody could get close to it.
Were you present when he took it into the bush to sort it out?
I helped him carry it into the bush, but it was then all left in his hands.

That is all for this witness, thank you Chairperson.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY

No questions for this witness, Mr Chairman.
NO CROSS-EXAMINATION BY

No questions, sir.
NO CROSS-EXAMINATION BY
